heading: tech stocks out in front
subheading: a week after the nasdaq crashed and burned, tech and net shares are again leading the market amid upbeat earnings and a vitamin-enriched pc industry. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: tech and internet stocks were zooming way ahead of the rest of the market monday as investors smiled on surprisingly strong numbers for first-quarter computer shipments and solid earnings. the nasdaq composite index jumped 50.66 points to 2641.35 in mid-afternoon trading, and the wired index was 9.62 higher at 681.53. much of those gains stemmed from a pair of stat factories, international data corp. and dataquest, reporting that the pc market is doing a whole heck of a lot better than people had thought, with demand for new machines rising as prices keep on falling.the dow jones industrial average shed 21.76 to 10667.91 after flirting briefly with positive territory. the blue-chip index was hobbled by union carbide warning that it's unsure of its second-quarter prospects, and by doubts surrounding drugmaker merck's future growth. the s&p 500 was up 0.41 at 1357.26."the world at large recognizes that the reason we don't have inflation is the productivity-enhancing impact of information technology spending," said ulric weil, an analyst with friedman, billings, ramsey. "the first inkling that this is not going to continue -- bad news. but for right now, it's a goldilocks world of low inflation, low unemployment, and people having lots of money."investors are rewarding favorite tech outfits for placing all that porridge on the table. ibm (ibm), which has been riding the up escalator since reporting white-hot earnings last week, advanced us$6.81 to $206.56 on word that the company is now mulling a higher dividend and a stock-buyback plan. dell computer (dell) climbed $1.69 to $44.69, and even struggling compaq computer (cpq) managed to ascend 19 cents to $23.31.netwise, online brokers were among the hot picks as us bancorp piper jaffray revealed that electronic stock trading rose 49 percent over the past three months to nearly 500,000 transactions a day. etrade group (egrp) appears to have been the engine for a good deal of that growth, and its stock vaulted 14 percent to $118.63 on news that it now boasts 1 million accounts. similarly, ameritrade (amtd) rose $8.88 to $135.88, and charles schwab (sch) was $2.63 higher at $123.31.investors will be paying close attention this week as some of the biggest names on the net post their latest results. america online (aol) gained $7.88 to $154.88 on hopes that the world's fattest online service will report profit of at least 9 cents a share on tuesday, while amazon.com (amzn) slipped $1.63 to $208.50 amid anticipation of a widening quarterly loss of 29 cents on wednesday.ebay (ebay) is slated to open its books after the market closes, and first-quarter income of 2 cents a share is expected. separately, the online auctioneer was up $11 at $211.13 on word that it will add some cachet to its offerings by purchasing the venerable butterfield & butterfield auction house for $260 million.should be interesting to see how well vintage port goes with pez dispensers.
